I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for  the  COVID-19  Active  Response  and  Expenditure  Support 
(CARES) Program under the Countercyclical Support Facility COVID-19 pandemic response 
option (CPRO).1 
 
2.  The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) and the economic shock triggered by the pandemic 
are dramatically reducing the employment, income, and well-being of Uzbekistan’s citizens. Since 
16 March 2020, wide-ranging social distancing and containment measures have been instituted—
including the suspension of all international and domestic travel, the closure of nonessential 
businesses  and  educational  institutions, and  compulsory  work  from  home  for  nonessential 
services.2 These measures have negatively affected the economy, with real gross domestic 
product (GDP) growth dropping to 1.5% in 2020 from a forecast of 6% before the pandemic.3 The 
downturn in global trade and lower demand and prices for commodity exports will widen the 
current account deficit to 9.6% of GDP in 2020 from an earlier forecast of 4.7%. The nationwide 
lockdown has led to 80% of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) suspending their 
activities. About $700 million of tourism revenues will be lost in 2020. The expected 40% decline 
in remittance inflows in 2020 will adversely impact the low-income families. The unemployment 
rate is projected to rise to 16.5% in 2020 from 9.4% in 2019. An additional 448,000 people are 
expected to fall into poverty. The widening of the fiscal deficit to 5.6% of GDP in 2020 (from an 
earlier forecast of 2.7%) has increased the urgent near-term financing needs. 
 
3.  The program will provide critical budget support to enable the government to undertake 
countercyclical expenditures to (i) strengthen the health system capacity to combat the spread of 
COVID-19; (ii) support businesses, employment, and job-creating regional public works; and (iii) 
expand  social  safety  nets.  Uzbekistan  meets  all  the  criteria  required  to  access  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) CPRO under the Countercyclical Support Facility, including robust 
macroeconomic management, undertaking of key structural reforms, a pro-poor countercyclical 
expenditure program, and public debt levels maintained at sustainable levels (Table 1).4 The 
program is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 (para. 21).5

3.  Pre-shock record  Uzbekistan has a strong record of sound macroeconomic management, achieving

rate liberalization, have been implemented since 2017. Under the inflation targeting 
regime, inflation has slowed from 17.5% in 2018 to 14.5% in 2019 and 12.9% in 2020.  
4.  Structural reforms  The Special Republican Commission was set up on 29 January 2020, followed by the 
Republican  Anti-Crisis  Commission  on  19  March  2020,  to  oversee  the  pandemic

operationalized  with  WHO  support.  The  government  has  undertaken  a  credible 
countercyclical response, including social protection measures. Coordinated support from 
development partners has been mobilized. The government remains committed to 
structural reforms to strengthen macroeconomic management. 
5.  Debt sustainability  ADB’s DSAa shows a low risk of debt stress. The budget support loans for COVID-19 will 
increase the outstanding public debt stock by 13.7% (6.1% from ADB and 7.6% from the

debt stress and will not impair debt sustainability. The IMF Assessment Letter and its 
DSA also confirm the low risk of debt stress.

II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
4.  Health care system. Uzbekistan’s health care system has not handled a pandemic or 
health crisis of this nature or scale since independence. On 11 March 2020, the World Health 
Organization  (WHO)  declared  the  COVID-19  outbreak  a  pandemic  with  serious  worldwide 
implications.6 Since the diagnosis of the first COVID-19 case in Uzbekistan on 15 March 2020, 
5,080 cases have been reported, corresponding to 150 cases per million population with 19 
deaths as of 15 June 2020. Although the country has made improvements over the years,7 the 
growing number of confirmed COVID-19 cases has placed a strain on the health care system, 
with  the  initial  diagnosis,  prevention,  and  treatment  capacity  constrained  by  shortages  of 
specialized  medical  staff,  facilities,  and  medical  equipment.8 Even  before  the  strict  social 
distancing measures were initiated, a Special Republican Commission headed by the Prime

Minister was set up on 29 January 2020 (Presidential Decree No. 5537) to (i) monitor the 
pandemic and raise public awareness,9 (ii) communicate with international organizations, and (iii) 
procure medicines and equipment to increase the health system preparedness and lower the 
spread rate of the virus.   
 
5.  Economy.  The  sharp  contraction  in  global  economic  activity  has  severe  economic 
consequences  for  Uzbekistan.10 The  pandemic  has  delivered  a  large  external  shock  to 
Uzbekistan’s economy, with real GDP growth projections falling to 1.5% in 2020 from the pre-
COVID-19 forecast of 6% (Figure). The economic impact and the knock-on effects on low-income 
households have been driven by the magnitude and duration of (i) the downturn in Uzbekistan’s 
main trade and investment partners; (ii) the fall in tourism revenues; (iii) domestic business 
disruptions, particularly SMEs; (iv) the contraction in remittance inflows; and (v) the widening fiscal 
deficit. The severity of the impact through these transmission channels is compounded by the 
risks from a second wave of COVID-19.11 Real private final consumption growth is projected to 
decline from 6.3% in 2019 to 0.3% in 2020. Real growth in gross fixed capital formation is 
projected to decline to 4.5% in 2020 from 46.0% in 2019. In 2020, real sector growth is projected 
at 2.1% for industry (8.9% in 2019) and 0.6% for services (5.5% in 2019), while growth in 
agriculture will remain stable at 2.6% (2.5% in 2019).

7.  Tourism. Tourist arrivals and revenues will fall sharply in this key growth sector. The 
number of visitors to Uzbekistan increased from about 1 million in 2016 to more than 6.4 million 
in 2018 and nearly 4.9 million in the first 9 months of 2019. This number of visitors was expected 
to rise to more than 7 million by 2025, with annual foreign currency earnings reaching $2 billion. 
The direct and indirect economic activity arising from tourism and travel related services reached 
about 4% of GDP in 2019.17 In the first quarter of 2020, tourist arrivals to Uzbekistan fell by 12% 
and tourism revenues are expected to decline by $700 million in 2020.  
 
8.  Small and medium-sized enterprises. With sales at a standstill and cash reserves 
depleted, SMEs have been hit hard. SMEs have been growing in Uzbekistan, providing 56.5% of 
GDP in 2019 and contributing 35% of industry, 84% of retail trade, and 52% of services. In 2019, 
SMEs’ share of exports was 28.7%, their share of imports was 54.2%, and their share of 
investment was 47%.18 SMEs account for 37% of formal sector employment and 78% of formal 
and informal employment combined. As of end April 2020, 13,000 public catering enterprises, 
45,000 retail enterprises, 19,000 service enterprises, and 7,000 transport enterprises  have 
stopped operating and/or lost significant revenue. About 80% of individual entrepreneurs have 
suspended their activities. Job losses caused by business closures carry the risk of large-scale 
unemployment, leading to reduced incomes and even social distress. 
 
9.  Remittances. Slowdowns in the Russian Federation and Kazakhstan are projected to 
result in a 40% fall in remittance inflows in 2020 compared with 2019. 19 About 13% (2.5 million) 
of Uzbekistan’s working-age population works abroad, with 85% in the Russian Federation.

10.  Poverty. Without social and economic support during the pandemic, the growing job 
losses, including for women, could reverse the gains made in poverty reduction since 2005.21 The 
World Bank estimates that an additional 448,000 people could fall into poverty, and the poverty 
rate (based on $3.20 per person per day in purchasing power parity terms) could increase to 8.7% 
in 2020 against the pre-COVID-19 projection of 7.4%.22 With 150,000 returning migrant workers 
and job losses from business closures, the unemployment rate is projected to increase to 16.5% 
in 2020 (from 9.4% in 2019 and against the pre-COVID-19 projection of 8.9% for 2020). 23 The 
Ministry of Employment and Labor Relations estimated that the number of unemployed citizens 
(including returning migrant workers) had reached more than 1.5 million as of 17 April 2020. From 
March to April 2020, the share of households with at least one member working fell from 85% to 
43% (footnote 20). Unemployment will be higher in the informal economy, which accounted for 
58% of total employment in 2019. Economic hubs in the Ferghana, Andijan, Namangan, and 
Samarkand regions  lead  in  informal  employment.  The  fall  in  remittances  will  contribute to 
increased poverty for low-income households.24 The median per capita income combined from all 
sources fell by 38% in April 2020 against March 2020, with a decline of 46% in urban areas and 
37% in rural areas. Declines in income have been largest among the self-employed (67%). The 
share of people unable to afford their basic needs was 12%, and people reporting reduced 
household food consumption reached 26% in April 2020. Women’s job prospects will be severely 
affected since they comprise about 45% of formal employees. Their share in SME employees 
reached 22.5% in 2016. In 2017, 43.2% of SMEs were managed and/or owned by women, with 
one-third of new businesses registered by women entrepreneurs.25 The pandemic has wiped out 
tourism and high-value horticulture exports, which affect women as they comprise 54% of workers 
in catering and trade and tourism, and 46% in agriculture and forestry.     
 
11.  Fiscal pressure. The pandemic is creating significant fiscal pressure. Budget revenues 
are expected to decline to SUM151.4 trillion (25.2% of GDP) in 2020 against the pre-COVID-19 
estimate of SUM159.0 trillion, driven by fall in taxes.26 Budget expenditures are expected to 
increase to SUM172.3 trillion (28.6% of GDP) in 2020 against the earlier estimate of SUM162.4 
trillion, driven by health and social expenditures and countercyclical spending. The IMF projects 
the overall fiscal deficit to be SUM33.8 trillion ($3.41 billion or 5.6% of GDP) in 2020 against the 
pre-COVID-19 estimate of SUM17.8 trillion ($1.86 billion or 2.7% of GDP).

1. Adverse Impact of  As of 15 June 2020, 5,080 COVID-19 cases have been reported with 19 deaths in Uzbekistan. The pandemic has 
Exogenous Shocks.  significantly impacted Uzbekistan’s export of natural gas, copper, cotton, textile and agriculture products, constrained 
supply chains and trade, reduced remittances inflows, halted transportation and tourism. Main risks to Uzbekistan’s 
economy arise from the uncertainty around the duration of health response measures that resulted in decline in 
domestic consumption and business disruptions, particularly for SMEs which represent 56.5% of GDP and provides 
78% of formal and informal sector jobs combined. Over 80,000 enterprises in food catering, retail trade, services and 
transportation have stopped operating due to social distancing measures introduced in March 2020. Uzbekistan’s real 
GDP growth is, therefore, projected to drop to 1.5% in 2020, from the initial forecast of 6% before the pandemic. The 
projected sectoral growth at constant factor prices in industry will drop from 8.9% in 2019 to 2.1% in 2020, and services 
from 5.5% in 2019 to 0.6% in 2020 while the growth in agriculture will remain stable at 2.6% in 2020 against 2.5% 
growth in 2019. The real growth of private final consumption is projected to decline to 0.3% in 2020, against the pre-
COVID-19 growth estimate of 10.4%. The real growth of gross fixed capital formation is projected to decline to 4.5% 
in 2020 against the pre-COVID-19 growth estimate of 8%. GDP per capita was expected to grow by 14.5% from 
$1,742 in 2019 to $1,995 in 2020 under pre-COVID-19 estimates. The revised projections indicate that per capita 
GDP will grow by only 3% to reach $1,795. The economic shock has dramatically reduced the employment, incomes, 
and wellbeing of citizens. The unemployment rate is projected to rise to 16.5% in 2020 from 9.4% in 2019 with layoffs 
and returning migrant workers. The median household incomes have declined by 38% in April 2020 (46% in urban 
areas and by 37% in rural and semi-urban areas). Income losses in the urban sector resulting from the lockdown 
measures have spillover effects on rural incomes and on the informal sector, thereby worsening the poverty situation.

2019, driven by fall in taxes. The pandemic is putting fiscal pressure on the government with the larger budget deficits 
expected in the second quarter of 2020, depending on the speed and breadth of disease spread. The government 
decided to lift its cap of $4 billion in total foreign borrowings to finance the pandemic response. The government plans 
to borrow from IFIs to finance the fiscal deficit. The uncertainty in the financial markets is constraining the liquidity 
options for the government, which just debuted with its Eurobonds in 2019. The sum depreciated by 6.7% against the

Development  the Presidential Decrees No. 5969, No. 5978 and No.5996 and established the ACF of SUM10 trillion under the

comprise (i) improving the capacity and preparedness of sanitary-epidemiological units, hospitals and quarantine 
complexes; (ii) addressing shortages in testing systems; (iii) procuring protective and diagnostic equipment, and (iv) 
providing salary supplements in the form of hazard pay for medical staff, directly affected by COVID-19. Main 
economic stabilization measures comprise (i) supporting affected businesses, including tourism, transport, and 
services through various tax incentives and loan deferments and (ii) creating jobs through public works in the regions.
